Award.AwardTitle: Instrument Development to Assess Design Project Appropriateness for Domain Relatedness, Ambiguity Tolerance, and Genderedness

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Industry-sponsored projects in the context of engineering design problems have received attention and prominence in undergraduate engineering education, yet the impacts of these experiences and learning gains for students is an important area of investigation for engineering education scholars. This project focuses on understanding the impact of three industry-sponsored project characteristics on student learning, project domain relatedness, project ambiguity, and project gender orientation. The goal of this project is to develop a new instrument to gain insight into design project appropriateness for first-year engineering students. Such findings are of significance not only to better design engineering education experiences, but also to gain insight into the impacts of such design experiences on student learning and their perceptions around engineering epistemologies and issues of student engagement. At a time of continued retention concerns in undergraduate engineering, results from this project have the potential to offer critical information to engineering educators around student engagement, project experiences, and impacts of industry-sponsored design projects.

Although there is an extensive body of knowledge around engineering design learning, there is limited knowledge on the appropriateness of industry-sponsored design projects integrated into the first year curriculum. This project adopts validated instruments on engineering student self-efficacy in combination with new survey instruments to be developed in order to gain insight into students' perceptions on the implications of an industry-sponsored design projects around characteristics of project domain relatedness, project ambiguity, and project genderness. With a large sample of data to be collected, statistical analyses will involve exploratory factor analysis, confirmatory factor analysis, as well as analysis of variance to isolate the significance of study variables (i.e., project domain relatedness to a student's chosen engineering major, project ambiguity, and project gender orientation). Knowledge gains from this project are expected to support strengthened partnerships between industry and academia, and to better understand the impacts of students' learning when working on industry-sponsored design projects.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Robin Havens Tate, Gul Okudan-Kremer, and Kathy L. Jackson have completed research validating an instrument that evaluates the appropriateness of industry-sponsored projects for undergraduate engineering design courses. In light of engineering education goals to expand the diversity of engineering students, industry-sponsored project choice is a vital component to help students feel they belong and are welcome members of the engineering profession. Currently, there is a research gap on engineering design project genderedness in undergraduate education. This study is a beginning step in this research area.

Student engagement in industry-sponsored engineering design projects is a vital component for successful first-year engineering education learning outcomes. However, a valid instrument to help faculty select, structure, and integrate industry-sponsored design projects into courses is lacking. Our study fills this gap by developing and validating a 22-item, 4-factor instrument assessing the appropriateness of engineering design projects in the following domains: student tolerance of ambiguity, student collective efficacy, project domain relatedness, and project gender orientation. To test the validity of this instrument, 811 students completed the instrument. Students were from two major United States research universities and the data collection took place over the course of five semesters. Results from both exploratory and confirmatory factor analyses support the 4-factor structure, demonstrated good discrimination power, and showed good convergent validity across students. Exploratory factor analysis of the instrument explains 64.922% of model variance, with project gender orientation explaining the most variation (25.058% of the model). Confirmatory factor analysis model fit indices suggest the four-factor model fits the data well: χ2 (188) =317.146, p < 0.001, RMSEA= 0.029 with 90% CI= (0.023, 0.035),    CFI= 0.990, TLI=  0.987, and SRMR= 0.0318. Projected Cronbach?s alpha for scores on the final 22-item instrument is 0.815, further supporting this is a reliable, valid instrument. Implications of the study, utility value of the instrument, and direction of future research are discussed.
